meeting_annotations.speaker: Feng Jiao
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sure I can I can just make a few comments that everyone can add to it. So our group mostly works on the catalyst development. So we actually have collaborators working on the theory side. You know, Yanyue Liu actually is one of our collaborators. We actually published a paper together last year. So one of the challenges we see in our experimental side is trying to understand the reaction intermediates, trying to figure out the reaction mechanism. Some of the tools we frequently use kind of probe the reactive intermediates but we have the trouble because the reaction intermediates usually have very short lifetime. And they are not really have a high coverage on the surface of the catalyst. So that's make even infrared or Raman become extremely difficult to see those intermediates. I think theory have a much better chance to really telling us what's going on the surface. And also I think on the other side I heard there are a few groups actually here also work on developing new tools to understand the electrochemical interface. I think it's definitely there's a need for us who working on the catalyst and also collaborate closely with people working on computational modeling and operando calculations. So that's my just two cents okay.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linsey Seitz
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry I I can jump in. I I definitely agree with that perspective that the spectroscopy experimentally is very tough. I think also the hard part about this is really just bridging the gap between idealized models and then really messy systems and so that really comes down to what what Feng was also saying about signal to noise. So other things I was thinking about was techniques like modulation excitation spectroscopy that we can use for experiment but that actually do they would be significantly enhanced if there's appropriate sort of theory or data processing to supplement that and I think it's having expertise from a theoretical perspective would help an experimental group like mine really make the most of these approaches.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yanyue Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry about this. Yes I also want to follow up on this. So I fully agree that the complexity in experiments is challenging for theorists. From computational side it's generally difficult to achieve a good balance between the accuracy and the efficiency. Sometimes we have to sacrifice the accuracy for efficiency so we can start for example we can start study large system we can study many materials but sometimes it's very important to consider those complex factors although they may cause significant computational cost. For example in I'm more familiar with the electrocatalysis and the solid liquid interface. So usually previously people often neglect for example the surface charge and also neglect the solvation explicit solvation and this approach this conventional approach is simplified but it's very successful in studying many different electrocatalysts because the computational cost is relatively low. However there are also many experiments that cannot be explained using such simplified approach and for those materials we really need to consider the for example the surface charge the explicit water solvation effect and without those consideration we cannot explain the experiments. So I think there is a strong need to develop and apply more advanced computational method to better understand the experiments.
